thread.title_full: Marine Le Pen, Francois Fillon ordered to quit the presidential race | World | News | Express.co.uk

author: Thomas Hunt
title: Marine Le Pen, Francois Fillon ordered to quit the presidential race | World | News | Express.co.uk
text:
He has no other alternative Francois Bayrou 
Fillon’s popularity dived following allegations that his wife was paid almost a million euros for a fake job. 
Fillon, the mainstream centre-right Republican party nominee, is adamant his Welsh-born wife, Penelope, did provide real work as his parliamentary assistant and he refuses to step aside. GETTY Heavyweight centrist Francois Bayrou has called for Francois Fillon to step aside. 
Penelope said in May 2007: “I have never been actually his assistant or anything like that. I don't deal with his communication,” shortly before her husband had become prime minister of then-President Nicolas Sarkozy. 
Bayrou said he would back the loser of the conservative ticket Alain Juppe if he replaced Fillon. 
He added that: "One cannot come up with a program that requires sacrifices from everyone, especially from those who are at the bottom of the pyramid, while reserving privileges for those who… have power.” GETTY Penelope Fillon has been accused of receiving almost a million euros for a fake job. 
Influential Les Républicains senator, Bruno Gilles, said the party had “turned the page” and wanted a new candidate. 
He told a Bleu Provence radio: ”This scandal is doing us more damage every day, and we can't wait another two weeks. There are presidential and legislative elections at stake and, beyond that, the survival of our political party." 
The senator added: "This could go as far as a party split." Get to know Marine Le Pen Sat, January 28, 2017 Marine Le Pen is a French politician who is the president of the National Front, a national-conservative political party in France and one of its main political forces. AFP/Getty Images 1 of 10 A French politician who is the president of the National Front (FN), a national-conservative political party in France and one of its main political forces. 
An opinion poll in the Journal du Dimanche showed that only 23 per cent of French voters now felt Fillon was honest, against 50 per cent last November. 
It comes after Le Pen launched her presidential campaign and vowed to make France “free again”. 
Criticising the EU at her rally, Le Pen said: “The European Union has placed us under guardianship, we will have to find a compromise with Europe to regain sovereignty.” Related articles
